sen.j: 灯籠（とうろう）は、日本の伝統的な照明器具の一つ。
sen.e: Toro (a garden lantern) is a kind of Japanese traditional lighting fixtures.
Toro (a garden lantern) is a kind of traditional Japanese lighting fixture.
Toro (a garden lantern) is a kind of traditional Japanese lighting fixture.

sen.j: 元は文字通り、灯（あかり）籠（かご）であり、あかりの火が風などで消えないように木枠と紙などで囲いをしたもので僧侶が用いたとされる。
sen.e: Toro originates from a basket containing a light, as literally meant by the kanji therefor (灯篭), more specifically, a lantern consisting of wooden frames and paper, etc. covering the frames to prevent the light from being blown out by a wind etc. which is assumed to have been used by a Buddhist priest.

Toro originates from a basket containing a light, as literally meant by the kanji (灯篭), more specifically, a lantern consisting of wooden frames and paper, etc. covering the frames to prevent the light from being blown out by the wind etc. which is assumed to have been used by Buddhist priests.

Toro originates from a basket containing a light, as literally meant by the kanji (灯篭), more specifically, a lantern consisting of wooden frames and paper, etc. covering the frames to prevent the light from being blown out by the wind etc. which is assumed to have been used by Buddhist priests.

sen.j: その後室内で用いるものは行灯（あんどん）、折りたたみ式で携帯も可能なものは提灯と分化した。
sen.e: Later, such a lantern came to be divided into three types: 'toro' (a lantern for outdoor use), 'andon' (a lantern for indoor use), and 'chochin' (a folding and portable lantern).
sen.cmt: この文だけでは、行燈と提灯の2種類に分化したと取れますが、そうではなく、後続の文で言及されている灯篭も含めて3種類に分化したと取るのが妥当と判断し、そのように訳出しました。尚、ここでの｛行燈」、「提灯」については、種別の名称に言及するものであり、日本語の名称を明記することが重要で、これらに対する定訳を当てることに意義がないので、名称だけをローマ字で表記しております。
sen.e: Later, such a lantern came to be divided into three types: 'toro' (a lantern for outdoor use), 'andon' (a lantern for indoor use), and 'chochin' (a folding and portable lantern).
Later, such a lantern came to be divided into three types: 'toro' (a lantern for outdoor use), 'andon' (a lantern for indoor use), and 'chochin' (a folding and portable lantern).

sen.j: 灯籠と言った場合、神社寺や旧街道などに多く存在する屋外の固定式を指すことが多い。
sen.e: Toro refers in many cases to such fixed lanterns for outdoor use as often seen Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines.
Toro refers in many cases to such fixed lanterns for outdoor use as often seen in Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines.
Toro refers in many cases to such fixed lanterns for outdoor use as often seen in Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines.

sen.j: また仏具としての室内用の灯籠（置灯籠・釣灯籠）や祭礼用などで移動可能なものもある（青森県のねぷた祭り、熊本県の山鹿灯籠など）。
sen.e: However, there also exists toro to be used indoor as a Buddhist altar fitting, such as oki-doro (one variety of nonbasic-type ishi-doro, which has no sao and therefore whose chudai is directly mounted on a natural stone serving as a base, note: the term "nonbasic" means that any of the basic parts of ishi-doro, that is, hoju, kasa, hibukuro, chudai, sao and kiso, is missing) and tsuri-doro (hanging toro), as well as portable toro for use in a festival.

However, there also exists toro which are used indoors as on a Buddhist altar, such as oki-doro (one variety of nonbasic-type ishi-doro, which has no sao and therefore whose chudai is directly mounted on a natural stone serving as a base, note: the term "nonbasic" means that any of the basic parts of ishi-doro, that is, hoju, kasa, hibukuro, chudai, sao and kiso, is missing) and tsuri-doro (hanging toro), as well as being a portable toro for use in a festival (such as one used in Nebuta Festival, which is held in Aomori Prefecture, and yamaga-toro used in Kumamoto Prefecture).

However, there also exists toro which are used indoors as on a Buddhist altar, such as oki-doro (one variety of nonbasic-type ishi-doro, which has no sao and therefore whose chudai is directly mounted on a natural stone serving as a base, note: the term "nonbasic" means that any of the basic parts of ishi-doro, that is, hoju, kasa, hibukuro, chudai, sao and kiso, is missing) and tsuri-doro (hanging toro), as well as being a portable toro for use in a festival (such as one used in Nebuta Festival, which is held in Aomori Prefecture, and Yamaga-doro used in Kumamoto Prefecture).

sen.j: 近代以前は港に設置され灯台としても使用された。
sen.e: (such as one used in Neputa Festival, which is held in Aomori Prefecture, and yamaga-toro used in Kumamoto Prefecture) In pre-modern times, toro was placed at a harbor to be used as a beacon.
In pre-modern times, toro was placed at a harbor to be used as a beacon.
In pre-modern times, toro was placed at a harbor to be used as a beacon.

sen.j: 光源としては、油やろうそくが用いられた。
sen.e: Oil or a candle was used as a light source.
Oil or a candle was used as a light source.
Oil or a candle was used as a light source.

sen.j: 現代では電気やプロパンガスによるものもある。
sen.e: Today, some of toro use electricity or propane gas to light the light source.
Today, some toro use electricity or propane gas.
Today, some toro use electricity or propane gas.

sen.j: 日本庭園における石灯籠のように実用ではなく装飾目的になっているものもある。
sen.e: There also exists such toro as is not practical but decorative, such as ishi-doro (stone-made toro) in a Japanese-style garden.
There also exists decorative toro that are not practical, such as ishi-doro (stone-made toro) in a Japanese-style garden.
There also exists decorative toro that are not practical, such as ishi-doro (stone-made toro) in a Japanese-style garden.

tit.j: 日本庭園における石灯篭

sen.j: 日本には飛鳥時代に仏教が伝来したのと同時に灯籠が伝来した。
sen.e: Toro was imported into Japan concurrently with Buddhism in the Asuka period.
Toro was imported into Japan concurrently with Buddhism during the Asuka period.
Toro was imported into Japan concurrently with Buddhism during the Asuka period.

sen.j: 初期はその多くが｢献灯｣と呼ばれ、仏閣（社寺）に設置されていたが庭園文化の発達と共に園内に鑑賞目的で設置されるようになった。
sen.e: Initially, many of toro were called 'kento' (referring to a votive lantern at a temple or shrine) and placed at a Buddhist temple (Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple); however, the development of culture associated with a Japanese-style garden resulted in toro coming to be placed in a garden in order to be appreciated.
sen.cmt: 仏閣（社寺）→Buddhist temples and shrines→Buddhist temple (Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple)庭園文化→gardening culture→teien bunka (culture associated with a Japanes-style garden)
sen.e: Initially, many toro were called 'kento' (referring to a votive lantern at a temple or shrine) and were placed at a Buddhist temple (Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple); however, the development of the culture associated with a Japanese-style garden resulted in toro coming to be placed in a garden, in order to be appreciated.

Initially, many toro were called 'kento' (referring to a votive lantern at a temple or shrine) and were placed at a Buddhist temple (Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple); however, the development of the culture associated with a Japanese-style garden resulted in toro coming to be placed in a garden, in order to be appreciated.

sen.j: 石質は花崗岩が主流で、その中でも御影石は石灯籠の中で最も多い。
sen.e: The mainstream of materials for ishi-doro is granite, and the variety of granite that is called 'mikageishi' is most commonly used for ishi-doro.
The mainstream of materials for ishi-doro is granite, and the variety of granite that is called 'mikageishi' is most commonly used for ishi-doro.
The mainstream of materials for ishi-doro is granite, and the variety of granite that is called 'mikageishi' is most commonly used for ishi-doro.

tit.e: Names of the parts of ishi-doro
Names of the parts of ishi-doro

sen.j: 上からの部分名称
sen.e: Listed in top-to-bottom order
Listed in top-to-bottom order
Listed in top-to-bottom order

sen.j: 宝珠（擬宝珠）
sen.e: Hoju (literally, a precious orb)/giboshi (literally, quasi-hoju)
Hoju (literally, a precious orb)/giboshi (literally, quasi-hoju)
Hoju (literally, a precious orb)/giboshi (literally, quasi-hoju)

sen.j: 笠の頂上に載る玉ねぎ状のもの。
sen.e: Hoju refers to an onion-shaped object mounted on top of kasa (a cap).
Hoju refers to an onion-shaped object mounted on top of kasa (a cap).
Hoju refers to an onion-shaped object mounted on top of kasa (a cap).

sen.j: 笠
sen.e: Kasa (cap)
Kasa (cap)
Kasa (cap)

sen.j: 火袋の屋根になる部分。
sen.e: Kasa refers to a part roofing hibukuro (burning place of toro).
Kasa refers to a part of the roofing hibukuro (burning place of toro).
Kasa refers to a part of the roofing hibukuro (burning place of toro).

sen.j: 六角形や四角形が主流であるが雪見型の円形などもある。
sen.e: In terms of shape, hexagonal and rectangular kasa constitute the mainstream; moreover, there exists kasa of other shapes, such as round-shaped one used for the yukimi type (a type of toro with a large cap and tripod (planted in a garden for ornamental purposes)).

In terms of shape, hexagonal and rectangular kasa constitute the mainstream; moreover, there exists kasa of other shapes, such as a round-shaped one used for the yukimi type (a type of toro with a large cap and tripod planted in a garden for ornamental purposes).

In terms of shape, hexagonal and rectangular kasa constitute the mainstream; moreover, there exists kasa of other shapes, such as a round-shaped one used for the yukimi type (a type of toro with a large cap and tripod planted in a garden for ornamental purposes).

sen.j: 多角形の場合は宝珠の下部分から角部分に向かって線が伸び、突端にわらび手という装飾が施されることもある。
sen.e: In some cases, polygonal-shaped kasa have a line extending from the bottom of hoju toward a corner of the kasa with warabite (a bracken sprout-shaped decoration) placed at the tip of the corner.
In some cases, polygonal-shaped kasa have a line extending from the bottom of hoju toward a corner of the kasa with warabite (a bracken sprout-shaped decoration) placed at the tip of the corner.
In some cases, polygonal-shaped kasa have a line extending from the bottom of hoju toward a corner of the kasa with warabite (a bracken sprout-shaped decoration) placed at the tip of the corner.

sen.j: 火袋
sen.e: Hibukuro (burning place of toro)
Hibukuro (burning place of toro)
Hibukuro (burning place of toro)

sen.j: 灯火が入る部分で灯籠の主役部分である。
sen.e: Hibukuro refers to a part to place a light in, which constitutes the primary part of toro.
Hibukuro refers to a part to place the light in, which constitutes the primary part of toro.
Hibukuro refers to a part to place the light in, which constitutes the primary part of toro.

sen.j: この部分だけは省略することができない。
sen.e: Unlike other parts, this part can never be omitted.
Unlike other parts, this part can never be omitted.
Unlike other parts, this part can never be omitted.

sen.j: 装飾目的の場合は火をともすことは無いが、実用性が求められる場合には火や電気等により明りがともされる。
sen.e: Hibukuro of toro for decoration purposes is not lit; however, that of toro for practical use is lit by the use of fire, electricity, and so forth.
Hibukuro of toro for decoration purposes is not lit; however, for toro for practical use are lit by the using fire, electricity, etc.
Hibukuro of toro for decoration purposes is not lit; however, for toro for practical use are lit by the using fire, electricity, etc.

sen.j: 中台
sen.e: Chudai (literally, a stand in the middle)
Chudai (literally, a stand in the middle)
Chudai (literally, a stand in the middle)

sen.j: 火袋を支える部分で最下部の基礎と対照的な形をとる。
sen.e: Chudai refers to a part supporting hibukuro and taking a form contrastive to that of the bottom part of toro, that is, a base.
Chudai refers to a part supporting hibukuro and taking a form contrastiing to the bottom part of toro, that is, the base.
Chudai refers to a part supporting hibukuro and taking a form contrasting to the bottom part of toro, that is, the base.

sen.j: 蓮弁や格狭間という装飾を施すことがある。
sen.e: This part may be provided with a decoration called 'renben'(literally, lotus petal) or 'kozama'.(carving).
This part may be decorated and is called 'renben'(literally, lotus petal) or 'kozama'.(carving).
This part may be decorated and is called 'renben' (literally, lotus petal) or 'kozama' (carving).

sen.j: 竿
sen.e: Sao (pole)
Sao (pole)
Sao (pole)

sen.j: もっとも長い柱の部分。
sen.e: Sao refers to the longest part serving as a pillar.
Sao refers to the longest part serving as a pillar.
Sao refers to the longest part serving as a pillar.

sen.j: 雪見型に代表される背の低い灯篭ではよく省略される。
sen.e: In the case of toro having a small height represented by the yukimi type, this part is often omitted.
In the case of toro having a small height represented by the yukimi type, this part is often omitted.
In the case of toro having a small height represented by the yukimi type, this part is often omitted.

sen.j: 円筒状が一般的であるが、四角形、六角形、八角形のものも見られる。
sen.e: Cylindrical sao is common, but rectangular, hexagonal, and octagonal sao are in existence.
Cylindrical sao is common, but rectangular, hexagonal, and octagonal sao are in existence.
Cylindrical sao is common, but rectangular, hexagonal, and octagonal sao are in existence.

sen.j: 節と呼ばれる装飾がよく用いられる。
sen.e: A decoration called 'fushi (節)' is often provide with sao.

sen.j: 基礎
sen.e: Kiso (base)
Kiso (base)
Kiso (base)

sen.j: 最下部の足となる部分である。
sen.e: Kiso is the bottom part of toro which serves as a leg.
Kiso is the bottom part of toro which serves as a leg.
Kiso is the bottom part of toro which serves as a leg.

sen.j: 六角形や円形が主流。
sen.e: Hexagonal-shaped and round-shaped kiso constitute the mainstream.
Hexagonal-shaped and round-shaped kiso constitute the mainstream.
Hexagonal-shaped and round-shaped kiso constitute the mainstream.

sen.j: 雪見型灯籠などでは3本や4本の足で構成される。
sen.e: Kiso for toro of the yukimi type (as explained above) consists of three or four legs.
Kiso for toro of the yukimi type (as explained above) consists of three or four legs.
Kiso for toro of the yukimi type (as explained above) consists of three or four legs.

sen.j: 春日型
sen.e: Kasuga type
Kasuga type
Kasuga type

sen.j: 神社仏閣で多く見られるもので実用性も高い。
sen.e: Toro of the kasuga type is often seen at a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple and has high practicality.
Toro of the kasuga type is often seen at a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple and is very practical.
Toro of the kasuga type is often seen at a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple and is very practical.

sen.j: 竿が長く火袋が高い位置にあるのが特徴である。
sen.e: It is characterized by the long length of sao and the high position of hibukuro.
It is characterized by the long length of sao and the high position of hibukuro.
It is characterized by the long length of sao and the high position of hibukuro.

sen.j: 園路沿いに設置するのが一般的。
sen.e: It is generally fronts on a garden path.
It is generally stands in the front on a garden path.

sen.j: 雪見型
sen.e: Yukimi type
Yukimi type
Yukimi type

sen.j: 雪見とは｢浮見｣が変化した語である。
sen.e: The term "yukimi" is a corruption of the term "ukimi" (literally, something that looks as if it were floating on a water surface).
The term "yukimi" is a corruption of the term "ukimi" (literally, something that looks as if it were floating on the surface of the water).

sen.j: 竿と中台が無いた為、高さが低い。
sen.e: Toro of this type is short because it has no sao and chudai.
Toro of this type is short because it has no sao and chudai.

sen.j: 主に水面を照らすために用いられるので笠の部分が大きく水際に設置することが多い。
sen.e: This is used mainly for lighting a water surface; therefore, it has large kasa and is often placed at the waterside.
This is used mainly for lighting the surface of the water; therefore, it has large kasa and is often placed at the waterside.

sen.j: 足は3本のものが主流。
sen.e: In terms of the number of legs, tripod type constitutes the mainstream of toro of the yukimi type.
In terms of the number of legs, the tripod type constitutes the mainstream toro of the yukimi type.

sen.j: 笠の丸い丸雪見と六角形の六角雪見がある。
sen.e: In terms of the shape of kasa, there are two types: 'maru-yukimi', which has a round-shaped kasa, and 'rokkaku-yukimi', which has a hexagonal-shaped kasa.

sen.j: 岬型
sen.e: Misaki type (type intended for placement at the seaside)
Misaki type (type intended for placement at the seaside)
Misaki type (type intended for placement at the seaside)

sen.j: 雪見型から基礎部分（足）を取り除いたもの。
sen.e: The misaki type is almost the same as the yukimi type; the only difference is that the misaki type does not have kiso (legs) while the yukimi type has.
The misaki type is almost the same as the yukimi type; the only difference is that the misaki type does not have kiso (legs) while the yukimi type does.

sen.j: 州浜や護岸石組の突端に設置する。
sen.e: The misaki type is placed at a sandy beach or at the tip of rockwork for shore protection.
The misaki type is placed at a sandy beach or at the tip of a pier for shore protection.

sen.j: 灯台を模したものである。

sen.j: 織部式灯籠
sen.e: Oribe type (this type name derives from Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA commonly known as Oribe FURUTA, who contrived toro of this type)
sen.cmt: 「織部式」の名称の由来を括弧内に併記しました。
sen.e: Oribe type (this type name derives from Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA commonly known as Oribe FURUTA, who contrived toro of this type)
Oribe type (this type name derives from Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA commonly known as Oribe FURUTA, who contrived toro of this type)

sen.j: 江戸時代の茶人・古田重然が考案した灯籠で、つくばいの鉢明りとして使用する。
sen.e: This type was contrived by Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA, an expert in the tea ceremony in the Edo period, and is used to light tsukubai (a stone washbasin).

sen.j: 四角形の火袋を持つ活込み型である。
sen.e: The oribe type is one variety of ikekomi type (one variety of nonbasic type ishi-doro which has no kiso and whose sao is directly recessed in the ground) having rectangular hibukuro.
The oribe type is one variety of ikekomi type (one variety of nonbasic type ishi-doro which has no kiso and whose sao is directly recessed into the ground) having a rectangular hibukuro.

sen.j: その為、高さの調節が可能である。

sen.j: 露地で使用される。

sen.j: 三月堂
sen.e: Sangatsudo type (one variety of basic-type, hexagonal-shaped ishi-doro deriving from the one made in the Kamakura period which is in front of Sangatsudo of Todaiji Temple) (Note: the term "basic-type" means having all six parts of ishi-doro, or hoju, kasa, hibukuro, chudai, sao and kiso.)
